instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Hey everybody, I've got <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC 3184 which doesn't turn on anymore

HISTORY : customer said that in the beginning on of the usb-c port stopped charging, then a week later another. So none of the ports are working.

MEASUREMENTS :

The mb pulls 5.24V - 0.15A on port closest to the screen
And 5.20V - 0.357A on port closest to the trackpad ))

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - on <CAPACITOR>C6481</CAPACITOR> - 12.32V
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> - 5.15V
<CHIP>U6940</CHIP> - pin1 = 3.28V, pin10 = 0V on <RESISTOR>R6941</RESISTOR>/40

Is the <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> (SLG4AP41183) dead ?

If I understood correct from the other thread it should have some voltage on pin 10 too

Thanks for your support

Regards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
The big difference of current consumption between the USB-C ports, points to a problem on that area.
Post voltage and diode mode to ground at LDO outputs of both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

"If I understood correct from the other thread it should have some voltage on pin 10 too"
Only if pins 3 & 4 are controlled correctly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
thanks for your reply

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V / diode mode 0.47
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.03V / 0.50
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V / 0.48
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V / 0.51

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 2.1V / 0.38
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0.03V / 0.50
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V / 0.37
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V / 0.51

<CHIP>U6940</CHIP> - pin3 - 3.28V, pin4 - 3.28V

Also I'm getting <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> warming up very quickly, no matter which port i plugin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
will do ))

I've got <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board it has [B]<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> CD3215B01[/B] do you think it can fit ?

From schematics look like the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
loool

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - is <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (my bad) 

spent an hour reballing a foking wrong chip )) hahaha

Placed [B]CD3215B01 [/B]from donor and was getting 20V on one of the ports, the other one stuck at 5V

Completely removed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (donor chip) and back to 5V 0.2A

Indeed is not the same code - needed part is CD3215C00

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
"Completely removed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (donor chip) and back to 5V 0.2A"
Both chips MUST be present on the board.

CD3215C00 can't be replaced with CD3215B01; internal firmware is different.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Ok just received and installed a new CD3215C00 getting same reading as with CD3215B01

One port takes 20V the other one 5V,  should both ports pulling 20V ?

On <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> now the readings are correct

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V / 0.48

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Both ports must have same behaviour.
Check the 4 connections possible also.

threads.message:
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

bmc went to 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
1V1 LDO (BMC voltage) is generated by <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, when powered.
Check for knocked off, or moved components; also broken traces.
Be sure to solder correctly the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
hmmm how is that even possible :cry: ðŸ˜…

ok i did all that 3 times(no exaggeration)  with exact same results (so we can exclude bad soldering)

when [U]original [/U]placed on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and connected to upper port i'm getting correct voltages on all LDOs and getting 20V on that port

when the replaced is on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> i'm missing BMC 1V1 - all others LDOs are good and getting 5V / 0.27A

when [U]original [/U]is placed on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> i'm missing BMC 1V1  - all others LDOs are good and getting 5V /0.27A

and when replaced is on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> i'm missing BMC 1V1 - all others LDOs are good and getting 5V/0.27A

is the replaced one is faulty ? If so why don't I get 1v1 when the original is on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> ?

ordered another two <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> will receive em soon

also tried with another dc dock

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
1V1 LDO must appear only on the powered port.
So, when you check it, connect the charger accordingly.

If you get 20V with original chip in place of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, at least you know that chip is good.
If the same port stays at 5V with any other chip, then none of them is good; considering all soldered correctly.
You should get a known good chip to solder into <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> place.

Also check all resistors related with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - not powering on [SOLVED]
threads.message:
